moves.4... Nxf2: I've never seen this before, and I'm sure it could be devastating provided that black pressures the exposed king early.
moves.5. Kxf2:
An interesting sacrifice, but, eventually, black does not press the exposure of the king.
5. ... Bc5  6. d4
moves.5... Qf6 6. d3 h6: Why h6?  Why not Bc5  or e5?
moves.10... g5 11. Ne5:
A double trap.  If ...
11. .. Bxe5 then
12. Bxa8!
If ...
11. .. c6 then
12. Rxf7!
moves.11... c6: Black sees the first trap, but maybe not the second.
moves.12. Rxf7:
12.	... 	Qd8
13.	Nxc6 	dxc6
14.	Qf3 	Rf8
15.	Rxf8  	Bxf8
moves.12... Qd8: If I move my rook, I lose my knight.  If I lost my knight, I lose my rook.  So, I try to pressure the trapped black rook at a8.
moves.13. Nxc6 dxc6 14. Qf3 Bb7: Trying to defend against the stacked Queen/Bishop, black forgets about the rook.
moves.15. Rxb7 Qc8 16. Qf7+:
Initially, I thought I'd move as follows:
16.	... 	Kd8
17.	Rxa7 	Rxa7
18.	Qxa7 ...
moves.16... Kd8: But, I see the fork to take the rook at h8.
moves.17. Qf6+:
At this point, there's two basic possibilities.  I set up conditional moves as follows:
17. ... Ke8 18. Qxh8  Bf8 19. Rh7
17. ... Be7 18. Qxe7
moves.17... Be7 18. Qxe7#: I certainly learned to be prepared for the possibility of 4. .. Nxf2 against Reti.
